intro: Benzingia chocoensis, commonly known as the Chocoan mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to the tropical regions of South America, particularly in Colombia and Ecuador. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its small, evergreen leaves and gelatinous berries that contain toxic compounds. The plant attaches itself to the branches of host trees, drawing water and nutrients through its haustoria, while performing photosynthesis independently. Its ecological role is significant in the rainforest ecosystem, influencing host tree health and serving as a food source for certain bird species. Due to habitat loss, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
